thread.title: Forty Percent of Transactions to be EMV Compliant by Deadline: Ritchie
thread.title_full: Forty Percent of Transactions to be EMV Compliant by Deadline: Ritchie

author: pbritt
title: Forty Percent of Transactions to be EMV Compliant by Deadline: Ritchie
text:
Posted by pbritt on Sep 1st, 2015 in Featured Stories , Mobile Payments Conference | 0 comments 
Nearly 40 percent of transactions will bed EMV compliant by the Oct. 1 date, when payment fraud liability shifts from the card issuers to the merchants, Chester Ritchie, senior vice president at Worldpay, told the audience during a keynote address at the Mobile Payments Conference in Chicago today. 
That 40 percent figure will be obtained primarily because Wal-Mart, Sam’s Club and Target recently turned on EMV capabilities at their stores, which handle a large percentage of U.S. transactions. Other big box stores, some large grocery conglomerates and a few other merchants have EMV capable terminals, but have yet to turn on the EMV feature. 
However, many other small and medium-size merchants have yet to upgrade to EMV-capable terminals. Fraudsters will shift their efforts to these merchants and to card not present transactions as of the Oct. 1 date, said Ritchie, pointing to the experience of European merchants once the continent adopted EMV more than a decade ago. 
“It’s important to make sure that payments are secure,” Ritchie said, pointing to the example of hackers compromising a POS system that was popular among restaurants and other small businesses. As a result of the security flaw, 1,800 small restaurants were breached, and the resulting costs resulted in many going out of business. 
If the industry doesn’t sufficiently protect payments from fraud, the government will step in with regulations, Ritchie cautioned. 
For ecommerce merchants and others involved in card not present transactions, Ritchie recommended that companies look at encryption, tokenization, secure vaulting and PCI 3.0. 
He cautioned that many vaulting solutions aren’t secure. PCI 3.0 is important because it removes sensitive customer information from the merchant’s systems. Share this:
